summary: Melvin Kreidman was an employee of the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). The documents available primarily relate to his employment records, including payroll authorizations, leave records, internal memoranda, and payroll certifications. These records span from 1977 to 1978, indicating his period of employment with the HSCA. A 1995 Final Determination Notification from the Assassination Records Review Board addresses the release of his HSCA staff payroll records, with his Social Security number postponed from release due to privacy concerns. The documents do not provide specific details about his role within the HSCA or his direct involvement in the JFK assassination investigation, but rather focus on the administrative aspects of his employment.
key_connections: U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA)
significance: Melvin Kreidman's significance lies in his employment with the HSCA, the committee tasked with investigating the JFK assassination. While the available documents do not detail his specific contributions to the investigation, his employment records are part of the broader collection of HSCA documents subject to review and potential release to the public.
